unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Type I Error: Efficiency Rating of a Boiler
question_text:
A new boiler is being advertised to have an efficiency rate of $91\%$. The company's competitor believes the new boiler is producing an efficiency rate of less than $91\%$. The company's competitor designs an experiment by randomly selecting 100 of the new boilers to test their efficiency rate.
Under which of the following conditions would a Type I error be committed?

choices.text: The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is less than $91\%$ when it is actually $91\%$.
The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is not less than $91\%$ when it is actually less than $91\%$.
The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is $91\%$ when it is actually $91\%$.
The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is less than $91\%$ when it is really less than $91\%$.
A type I error cannot be committed in this situation.

solution:
A type I error occurs when the null hypothesis is rejected (meaning the alternative hypothesis is taken) when really the null hypothesis is actually true.

In this case, the null and alternative hypotheses are:

${ H }_{ 0 }:$ The efficiency rate of the new boiler is $91\%$.
${ H }_{ a }:$ The efficiency rate of the new boiler is less than $91\%$.

The alternative hypothesis if the efficiency rate of the new boiler is less than $91\%$ as this what the company's competitor is trying to prove.

The type I error would be the company's competitor rejecting the null hypothesis and finding the efficiency rate to be less than $91\%$ when really it is $91\%$.

Please add Explanation of Distractors Choice 'B' is incorrect as this is the explanation of a Type II error in the context of this situation. A Type II error is when we fail to reject the null hypothesis when we should have rejected the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative. Choice 'C' is incorrect as we never accept the null hypothesis. Choice 'D' is incorrect as this is the explanation of power in the context of this situation. Power is when we correctly reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative.
